On 08/03/2008, Stephen Waits <steve@...> wrote:

>  That said.. there's really no reason not to use a good PRNG.


I totally agree. I just wanted to make the point that NEAT research
performed to-date with potentially poor PRNG's most probably isn't
lessened in value or invalidated at all.

Colin.
